review: Over one month after the release of this game and I am still experiencing major drops in framerate when simply walking around. This should not be happening when my rig is the following i7 6800K 6 core processor32GB DDR 3200MHZ RamDual EVGA GTX 1080 SC running in SLINvidia Control Panel set to automatically choose the SLI config and set to "Let the 3D App Decide" (meaning using the game settings with no further tweaking)I'm running Windows 10 and have disabled the Game DVR on the Xbox app per the Bethesday support site. No help at all.Really really wish I could play this game because I absolutely loved the original version of Skyrim and am always excited for a remaster. But given the recent slew of positive reviews for this one I felt I had to post this to let Steam and Bethesda know that there are still people out there with absolutely top notch rigs that cannot play this game. Please fix your broken game. Thanks.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. As I am a Skyrim Legendary maniac there's only a way I could call this game a total disappointment. Game is poorly optimized and lag is persistent on every graphic quality even on a beast machine like mine which can run other games just fine around 50 60 fps. Graphics are not that better just some textures were changed to make characters more "characters". Game occlusion and ENB are ridiculous two vertical bars constantly on screen show a damaged/broken graphic setting somewhere Enhancements are minimal rocks or plants here and there minimal weather fixes and such. Basically looks like they have installed public mods on the Special Edition. Really? Public mods won't be supported anymore that is to say if you play with material from the Nexus you won't be able to save your game. But apparently Bethesda is working on a Mod System similar to Fallout 4. Game crashes here and there or just gets stuck on the main menu forcing a shut down. No real stuff was added it's like they had to make some fast cash by selling an old product with a better repaint. Good thing they gave it to me for free.I am a HUGE fan of this series and Bethesda in general but this was really a kick in my face.So thanks but no thanks I will stick to the regular Legendary edition I already had for years.If you have it already don't spend a single copper on this "Special Edition" game at least until they will fix the mess they have done already.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

I was even using the unoffical patch before even playing for the first time so I could not suffer from the bugs at the cost of Achievements. I couldn't use my mouse buttons for attacking/blocking when I entered Helgen Keep Dragonsreach looks like the flickery mountains in the orginal game I've seen npcs floating in the air when you sneak slowly foward you tail is being tazered Alvor doesn't have the shop dialouge during vendor hours and more.The graphical improvements only somewhat noticable but the sound is noticably worse... at the cost of losing half of my fps my load order and my mostly bug free gameplay.I hope modders will come in and save this game but I cannot recommend it to anyone who has played a modded skyrim playthough before special edition.

Now 20% more subtle and 300% more aggressively forced!After adding payed mods to the workshop some time ago and miserably failing because of angry customers the workshop was completely removed now for the special edition and the original game (with workshop support) hidden from the store. Instead you now pay for mods or manage everything manually outside of steam using nexus mods etc. Mod compatibility was broken of course so you rather go for the paid ones.Keeping a game alive and interesting with mod support and an active community is no longer wanted. That may be good to make a name for your company but once you have it you have to milk money. You're not supposed to play a game released 6 years ago unless you start paying again! You're hurting the whole industry with that anti capitalist behavior! It's like playing with the same box of lego bricks for years how do you make a profit from that?!And why some more money out of an old title with creative scamming models? Come on everyone is doing it these days. Getting payed for nothing is much more cost efficient than getting payed for say another TES installment. You just have to be smart in the exciting and innovative world of e scamming! You owe it to the shareholders.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. I first got Skyrim on the Xbox 360 when it came out. The game was unlike anything I had ever played before and even after my Xbox was sold off for some cash I bought it on PC and started from scratch. I spent far far too much time on this game and frankly... this 'update' wasn't needed. The original to be fair has dated a little but not enough to warrant a remake. I honestly would've expected Morrowind or Oblivion to recieve the make over treatment (which they both definitely need because my god they look like trash compared to Skyrim). This Special Edition also doesn't really add anything that mods in the original couldn't of done except the graphics hike isn't optional and if you're playing on a sub par computer like me isn't good. At least with the original I can pick and choose my graphical mods to customise my experience sure it might look a bit worse than the Special Edition... but I can run it.All in all I feel like this was just to milk the popularity of a modern classic from the 12 hours I've played nothing but graphical stuff and a few little immersive things have been added. Again this is all stuff you can get in the original with mods. They should've only released this for console I feel and added more graphical options for PC rather than a new game that can't have it's graphics lowered.However I appreciate Bethesda for quite literally just giving me the Special Edition I feel like that was a great move on their part. But Oblivion/Morrowind should've got this Special Edition not Skyrim. But if your PC can run this then enjoy it's still Skyrim.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Finished it 2 5 times already on original version just to understand the complete story from both sides. Revisit again this time on Remastered Special Edition for good old time shake and never been so happier in my life. Though I still remember most of the quest and places it just cant make me stop to play it again. Try different route and character build and after all this time I still found many new things that I never encounter before from my old playtime. 44 hours gameplay so far and I even not yet visited another town except Whiterun and Winterhold.. lolThough some people think that this remastered are not quite what they're expected I'm still thinking that with all this new improvement and new features on graphics section are more than worth it to revisit Skyrim. The already beautiful world of Skyrim are getting for me much significant upgrade and improvement. That makes me wonder in awe while riding my horse just fooling around enjoying the scenery. On the down side some of the old bug from original game are still there and Bethesda like always are not quite fast to patching that bug or other problem that annoying in the game. Though finger crossed so far I never encounter any game breaking error or bug that most of the people having on the discussion forum. I hope mine stays fine )

review: Product received for free. Me loving Skyrim aside the game has vastly improved performance than it did before even w/o 64 bit enabled. I have played Skyrim on 4 different computers over the years including with both an AMD 8350 and i5 4790 with the technically superior GPU being a 660 GTX. I always had lag. I currently use a 745 4GB OEM which normally is terrible at rendering textures. I can run Skyrim with mostly Ultra High settings and a stable non laggy FPS at 1080. I'm really looking forward to seeing how the game plays with a better GPU and some modding but it is nice not to be required to mod the game just to reach the quality level it is at currently. For those with a modded Skyrim that they are pleased with it is a better option until (and if) more mods come along but as far as the baseline this 64 bit version is superior all around. Specs i5 4790. 16GB RAM 745 GTX 4GB Win 8.1

review: Product received for free. All right so Sepcial Edition is out. Well it looks better yes. That's about it. Nothing's improved really except some minor graphics. It still needs mods. A lot of them. With them it will be an awesome game since it's Skyrim...But the question really is is it worth buying? The answer is simply HELL NO. No way whatsoever should you pay money for this. Good thing us PC users did not have to and that is the only really positive thing Skyrim Special Edition has going for it.EDIT Also THIS COULD HAVE BEEN AN OBLIVION REMASTER! Oblivion is ing amazing. I am still playing it and have an active save to this very day...
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. First off I'll acknowledge the hate around this game and even state why people aren't too happy with this game It's a repeat of the previous one only with a few things added/changed.What exactly was added? A new and improved 64 bit engine Sun rays Realistic rain (doesn't clip through rooftops) Realistic water movement (doesn't just flow in a generic direction)That's not a lot at all for a new game that (maybe) took them a few years to develop. I completely understand why a lot of people are outraged regarding this new game given it adds almost nothing new. No bugfixes textures are still horrible etc. I'm also at a loss for why Bethesda had so much time to enhance the game yet added mediocre things. I will however say that I enjoy this game way more than the previous one despite these mediocre additions.Why I enjoy SE more than its predecessorFirst off the original Skyrim's 32 bit engine is pettiful. I have a GTX 1080 and the game runs at a choppy 40fps average with no mods installed. It does get 60fps no problem but as soon as I enter Markath I get hit with fps lag. In the original Skyrim you can't spawn a lot of enemies too easily either. It crashes too much. In SE you can spawn 500 bandits no problem. If I do the aforementioned spawning my fps drops to about 15. That's a damn good thing btw. Sure some of the bandits fly into space but I can actually still play after that performance hit.Secondly the lighting rain and water overhaul looks brilliant. Just go look at the screenshots for SE (ignore the flying horse that's normal for a Bethesda game).Thirdly the game has a 64 bit engine. I know I (technically) mentioned this in the first pointer but this is about the modding side. So many people complain/boast that their modded Skyrim looks so much better than SE. Sure it does. It's damn logical it does. This game just came out and has almost no mods in comparison to the old Skyrim. I do understand why they do this though as Bethesda had so much time to work on a proper re texture that would look much better than any modder's re texture. Ever think of performance? Skyrim can be run on almost any system. I do not know of one person who can't run Skyrim on their laptop or even mac. Now imagine Bethesda re textured Skyrim with super high res textures. They'll lose maybe 12% of their audience. Wait a few months and the texture mods for SE will outperform any texture mods for Skyrim no problem (hense the 64 bit engine).Would I recommend this gameWell... Yes and No. Here's why Do you own Skyrim LE and have received this game for free? Click install already. It's a damn good improvement. Do you own Skyrim but do not own all the DLCs? 1) If you've recently played Skyrim and are unsure about SE don't get it. Simple as that. Wait a year or so and if you're still interested get it. 2) You haven't played Skyrim in quite some time and are unsure about SE get it if you can. It boasts way better performance than Skyrim (I get 60fps average everywhere I go no matter what I do). You do not own Skyrim at all and are unsure about which one to get Wait for SE to become more stable and get more mods then pick it up if you can.Final note I want to add People who are against SE merely for the mods in Skyrim being better... Stop it. Just... Stahp plz. Given SE's 64 bit engine I'm quite sure Skyrim's modding community might slowly deteriorate until there are no more mods at all. SE will be able to run so much more mods at a time and still have amazing performance. People will want to rather mod SE than Skyrim. Sure you'll still have support. But right now all eyes are on the SE side of modding.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. My opinion of this game is a little wierd and I might get some hate for it but hear me out.Five years ago I bought this game for the 360 still new to the gaming world and at the time didn't even know Steam existed this was however not the first RPG I had played as in I had played Morrowind quite a bit as a kid. I stayed up for hours and hours playing the orginal release talked with my friends about it in my small town of &gt 5000 everyone I went to school with had atleast played the game. I played it for a good two years straight it was my go to game. After the first 2 years DLC came and went I got busy and play on and off till I eventually got rid of my 360 and then soon after move over to Steam and good ol PCMR.Within my first year of owning a PC for the intent of gaming I bought Skyrim at full price giddy with the knowledge of mods and console commands being able to fix those god forsaken bethesda bugs and adding new content to the game. I modded it a bit and after messing around with SKSE I got it to run. I think I played for a total of like 10 hours the orginal appeal of the game had been lost for some reason or another still not sure why if it was the controller being different the gameplay differences or the modding. Sometimes no amount of no amount of horse armor mods can save a game from just not being interesting anymore.When I found that I recieved this game for free because I owned the orginal and the DLC I thought it was kinda funny me and a friend joked about it even got this game for free and literally not sure who on PC would even ask for it. Yes it is a bone for the console community this game was probably released to Steam because they didn't want any hardcore PCMR bros getting off and ranting about console exclusives. I literally installed this game as a joke knowing that mods didn't work on SPE and how much I didn't enjoy the game on PC before.This game made me want to play Skyrim again the fact that you couldn't mod it felt like a more pure experience kinda like you're forced to play a game the way it is a feeling I had forgotten about since moving to PC. I never had many problems with the vanilla game on 360 and I felt more like I was playing a remaster of a console game than a true PC game which yes I know I said that it is a console game more than a PC game. This game really and honestly did not need to be released for Steam the graphic update is from the free dlc they made for Steam back a couple years ago. This game in a sense took me back as in the dreaded word of all reviews and opinions that completely and I mean this non sarcastically ruin it.Nostalgia. This game gave me hardcore nostalgia to the days of being a kid in high school dealing with homework and trying to impress girls the nights of staying in the living room all night eating junk food and playing a video game in the dark wrapped in a blanket. The weekends of friends coming over and taking turns playing a single player game rather than a multiplayer game because of how much fun we were having with it. Those hours and hours of looking up cool items in the game and where the best loot is and what cool stuff we could do with our characters. This game gave me the feels reminding me of friends I had lost to the tide of time all the time I had bleed into this game before I knew the horrors of the video game industry and the curse of DLCs and microtransactions. Let me make this clear this very important fact of what I'm saying.Nostalgia is a .Nostalgia 100% ruins the legitimacy of my review and my opinion of this game. It is not a solid ground to stand on when stating anything I know this and everyone reading my review should know this. A game is not good because it gives you nostalgia you should judge a game solely based on it as a game and so I will. This game is fun has a lot of stuff to do and in a very sarcastic sense has everything you enjoyed from Skyrim Orginal. This is just a update to the graphics and engine as so I heard. I've gotten my fair share of glitches crashes bugs getting stuck in objects and graphics going to because of draw distance. Seriously though this game has had no updating other than graphics and engine. That exploit you could do 5 years ago? Yeah its still there you can do all the old exploits and glitches bugs haven't been fixed and nothing is patched. Bethesda is just another triple A or AAA gaming studio that wants money cash cheddar caps and septims. I would say no new bugs but I've gotten stuck in objects a lot more than I remember. Would I say get this game for 40$? No lol if you got it for free thats great but if you want this exact game with mod support just buy the orginal with DLC during a good sale. I personally enjoy this game as it is and I have no desire to mod it in any way. This game gave me the feels and the dreaded N word of opinions. Uh the Nol starting word of opinions. Game has me in a good mood to play RPGs even got me to play some more Fo4. Just to make the record clear I have no positive opinions of Bethesda solely playing their games because I enjoy the game.So get the game if you want to play some vanilla Skyrim if not than buy the orginal release for mod support or just play a RPG thats not Bethesda heard they're pretty good.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: After reading a few reviews over this I've summed up one argument that I thought was particularly important to look at."It's not SUPPOSED to be a remake. It's a port!" This is true... but they've advertised it as a remake emphasizing GRAPHICS in order to make their sales. People have argued that nobody should buy this for graphics and they're right if you own this for PC there's absolutely no reason to purchase this again if you didn't obtain it for free. The fact of the matter is even if it is only a port it wasn't advertised that way. Technically that's false advertising.Skyrim is an extraordinary game. Even if its lore has been dumbed down compared to previous Elder Scrolls titles. However the Special Edition isn't worth $40. Not unless you don't already own it. The visuals are improved minorly with a few details like better shaders lighting and environmental effects like fog. It does run a little smoother but no previous game bugs are fixed which certainly proves ones point that it's merely a port. My biggest complaint is as mentioned before it's advertisement as something more. The Special Edition changes virtually nothing graphics wise and literally nothing in terms of gameplay. You'll be sorely disappointed if you're purchasing this because "gwaphix!" or are expecting some form of new content. There is none.This is a money grab. But not necessarily for PC gamers. Bethesda has given us the liberty of obtaining it for free if we've owned the previous edition before a certain date. That's all fine and dandy but the point of this re release was to obtain some revenue from console gamers. I definitely cannot complain it was free since I've owned a copy of Skyrim already on the PC. But everyone seems to miss the point that it IS port meant to improve gameplay for CONSOLE gamers to get MONEY from them. Not from us. If you don't already own Skyrim then perhaps the $40 price tag isn't a big deal. I would personally wait for a sale if I didn't already own it but that's just me.To conclude Skyrim Special Edition does NOT add anything new. My negative recommendation comes solely from the fact that I know people are only looking to buy it because they're expecting "new new new!" it's just Skyrim wiped over with a lavender scented wash cloth.EDIT Bethesda's mod browser is also absolute Steam Workshop was a far better and more convenient option and it was actually reliable. For those of you who didn't heed my warning and bought the game only to be disappointed by Bethesda's mod browser just find a tuturial on Nexus Mods. It's a lot easier than you think and beats the hell out of whatever Bethesda was trying to pull.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: I've got a GTX 1080 32GB of highspeed DDR3 ram 3770k processor SSD 4k ASUS Gsync monitor at 160+hz and this game runs like CRAP! When running at 4k I can get about 110 frames initially but then it starts having violent stutters to 70 80 frames and then eventually crashes down to a steady 10 frames. There is no reason this should be happening! This game is very poorly optimized and they need to resolve this quickly. I bought the final DLC on the last day so I could upgrade to Special Edition and it turns out it really was not worth it. Buyers beware!

review: Product received for free. I recommend this game but my opinions at launch are somewhat mixed. Allow me to try to make this as concise as I can.1. God rays and rain occlusion are a very nice touch. A+2. Enhanced clothing textures are noticeable but things like quivers still don't close up to the body. 3. 64 bit. This is what will keep the game running for the next decade or two THIS is the core reason to have this version. 4. Lots of same bugs as before some new ones too. I don't get this part at all. and it's just sloppy. Mods fix this google "unofficial skyrim patch". I expected to not see wolves falling from the sky.5. Audio files have been downgraded but not overly noticeable for me with current headphones. Please release original or actual remastered audio files please.6. I noticed a significantly improved load time. That's a nice plus.7. Viewing distances seem much improved with much less graphical hit than in the past. Could just be me. 8. Alt tabbing no longer crashes the game or mucks it up. Alt tab first try goes to black screen second try (hold alt tab) allows me to navigate. Improvement I guess.If you own a previous version but weren't eligible to get the remaster for free don't bother. Hold off til it's cheaper and fixed. If you have the ability to download this free go for it. Just be warned that it will likely be a downgrade with stock settings versus your old modded version. Give it til 2017 for a full modding experience to come to fruition. I got Skyrim Collector's Edition day 1 at midnight and I've spent more hours in this series than I'd like to admit. Having said that it appears to be a cash grab for the console peeps. At least it's 64 bit. I'll let the modding community fix what Besthesda won't do.All settings to max. Rx470 8gb Nitro 1090t 16gb RAM installed on WD Black HDD. 1440p 28fps and jittery in Riverwood and a few odd places 80 100+ fps indoors. Outdoors varies but seems to range from 40 60fps.

If anybody is hearing a buzzing sound instead of normal audio force quit the game immediately! Note that this crash occurred while playing vanilla Skyrim. I hope Bethesda fixes this soon because I love Skyrim and want to get back into it.The problem firs occurred when I entered some old Dwemer ruins around Windhelm and it's possible that's what caused the problem. However the game (after the factory reset) is completely broken and when I tried to load it up again it nearly crashed my computer once more. There is no way for me to determin if that dungeon was or was not the problem and I dare not open the game again.

review: Product received for free. I can't really reccomend Skyrim Special Edition that much. Sure it's still good old Skyrim including all of its previously released DLC from 2011 but (slightly) graphically updated... However you could achieve much better looking graphics out of the original Skyrim with mods. Sure you could get mods for Skyrim Special Edition... but you need some sort of Bethesda account whereas in the original you had the Steam Workshop by your side!Oh and yes this is a Bethesda game so don't expect them to have bug tested this game before release. There are a fair few new bugs. For example in the opening cutscene before you create your character Lokir the guy who gets shot trying to run away cries "NOE! AM NOT A REBOL. YOU CAHNT DO THIS D &lt " as per usual but after that nothing happened. He just stood there and the guards stared at him in silence. I had to start a new game to fix this bug. An assortment of old bugs carried over from the original too.Actually all of the bad from the original carried over to this edition. These "bad " include AI Broken (but admittedly hilarious) Stealth NPCs talking to me when passing by for no apparent reason NPCs repeating quotes over and over and over again Lack of Quest Variety (go here kill this go there talk to this guy) Immortal Children Uninteresting Combat Horseback Riding Gets boring after a while"But Yoshi you can solve the majority of these problems with mods!"Oh sure let's encourage the developers to let the consumer fix their game for them. That argument is invalid. Idle hands are the devil's workshop you s.Overall though I never was that fond of Skyrim to begin with it does have its moments and I would much rather reccomend you go buy the original.At least this still happens http //steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id 788655692

review: If you can acquire the original Legendary release instead do that.While the Special Edition is nice in principle it simply falls short on every level 1) Graphics. The game assets are virtually identical to the original's HD textures. The updated game engine does allow for some added effects which can be really nice but they can also contribute to a "polished turd" look generally. It's a mixed bag.2) Sound. The Special Edition sounds like garbage compared to the original release. The existing uncompressed audio assets have been mangled under an "updated" encoding scheme here and the results are pretty bad. It's a shame particularly given how rich and immersive the original sound design was.3) Mods. The Special Edition jettisons the Steam Workshop in favor of Bethesda's own mod host. It's pretty obvious that Bethesda is just waiting to pull the trigger on paid mods again it's only a matter of time. It seems that the Nexus is still a viable modding option though. Regardless by the time Special Edition compatible mods reach any sort of maturity you'll undoubtedly be able to catch this game on a sale anyway.So yeah for a $40 asking price this "Special" release just doesn't quite cut the proverbial mustard. Find yourself a copy of the prior Legendary Edition if you're looking to dive into The Elder Scrolls V experience. Maybe by this time next year the Special Edition will have evolved beyond it's current disappointment.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: This game is really a shame. I know there are a lot of people complaining about this being a cash grab but I just loved this game when it originally came out and despite my better judgement I went ahead and bought it.The remaster is really beautiful and the game is just as I remember it however it is clearer than ever that this is a Bethesda game. The bugs in this border on gamebreaking. Somehow this remaster takes all the bugs that existed with the original game and has made them worse. I'm constantly looking up console commands to attempt to fix issues in the game. I can't use any ability that slows time as it ends up staying slowed permanently (Kinda neat for 5 seconds then really annoying) The combat music loops without end after you have finished a fight. I actually had to turn off the in game music because it was driving me insane. I've gotten stuck in the ground more times than I can count with no explanation as to why forcing me to noclip out. This is just a handful of the issues I've had without getting into the silly stuff like NPC's walking away from you during dialogue breaking quests shouts not working (Always fun to line up the perfect shout just to have it decide it doesn't want to work this time) and just overall shoddy programming for a full price game. The worst part is I barely have over 20 hours playtime and have this many RECURRING issues. These aren't just one off bugs they happen over and over consistently. I love the Elder Scrolls games but this is a truly pathetic showing from such a big name developer and truly not worth the price or your time. Really hope they up their game for TES 6 or it could well be the last in the series.

review: Product received for free. I will get straight to the point If you don't have either this version or the regular Skyrim I would rather recommend to buy the old Legendary Edition than this when it is on sale or somewhere else. Don't get me wrong the Special Edition is really good and the renewed lighting and the rest do look really good that is why I still give this a Recommendation but now that I have completed the 100% Achievements on both games I can say without any doubt that there are no changes with the gameplay at all (even though I did not expect any changes anyway). Also there are mods for the old Skyrim which make it look better maybe even better than the Special Edition and you can get it for less money.Simple list Arguments for buying the Special Edition Looks Good Reason to get into Skyrim again if you have stopped playing Comes with all DLC ALT + TAB worksArguments for buying the regular Special Edition instead Mods from the Steam Workshop can make it look atleast as good as the Special Edition if not even better Has the same Gameplay and may be bought even cheaperBut if you don't want to deal with mods and don't care about money I will not stop you from enjoying the vanilla Skyrim with this.

review: I feel I have to write a bad review for this game.It's as full of bugs as the original. Other than some graphics improvements there is little different apart from the ability to add mods from the game......however the mod you really need is the unofficial legendary patch from Nexus. Installing this to make the game run without frequent crashes makes this game 'modded'. That disables your steam achievements. Presumably Bethesda believes that making the game run properly is cheating!I had the original version but got this to see what it was like. I didn't want to write a bad review so I wrote no review at all until now.What tipped me over the edge was Bethesda's forthcoming 'creation club' which I don't want but will be forced on me if I ever play the game online. I miss not being able to chat to friends while playing or stream my gameplay to them but I feel like I have no choice.Don't buy it unless you want Bethesda's daft 'creation club'.

review: Product received for free. Aleady deleted. Sure there are some nice additions and improved quality graphics but some very basic core flaws were left untouched. I would say I represent the lowerend users not so much a "casual" but closer to casually equipped hardware wise. Where you may have thrived in plain skyrim heavily modded you will probably stutter on ultra and if you're not playing on ultra then there is no point playing Special Edition. Maybe I'm spoiled but that carriage ride was like pulling teeth! The waiting was the worst only to be reminded what a vanilla character creation experience is all about kinda sapped any enthusiasm I had left. I might suggest SE to someone on console who has never heard of or played skyrim before but as of right now Special Edition for PC is not worth paying money for I'm going to assume no pc user paid money for this . One day this may emerge as the better version as it does have much potential but that will rely on the modding community yet again if they are not already disenfranchised.

review: Product received for free. Okay I'm not going to sit here and tell you this is the greatest game of all time but it is pretty damn good. The one thing I have a problem with in this game is the punishment for using mods. The one true selling point Bethesda used and drove home with the remastered Special Edition which was the inclusion of MODS. Will get you cut off from Achievements in the game. WTF?! You're going to incorporate this in the menu of the MAIN screen that allows you to download mods from YOUR website which we have to sign up to "Bethesda.net" and then punish everyone for doing so. You can say that this gives people and unfair advantage or it isn't how you intended the game to be played. After 6 years of playing this game why do you honestly give a damn if people use mods or Console commands for that matter? Further more if you're that opposed to people using mods in your game why make it accessible in he game itself. That's like building a Resturant that you've always wanted to eat at in your Town or city.Then anyone who goes there can look at all the food but if they ever eat any. They get poisoned and die. That's a bit extreme I know but it's fairly close. I'm sure I'm not the only person with this gripe but seriously this is really unfair to pull on people unsuspectingly. Bad form in my opinion.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Oh no no no no no!You just couldn't contain yourself could you bethesda? As if the special edition itself was not stupid enough to sell alone but you had the dignity to add in the creation club even after the overwhelmingly negative response you get? Its like your actively trying to shoot yourself in the foot so many times that it turns into a pool of bloody paste and lead!I'll get straight to it the Special Edition is a disgrace in almost every way. You get it for free if you alredy own the base game. But if you dont have it you have to pay $40 for a game which has 5% of the community content that the base game has which in my opinion is what drives its huge replayability. Not only that but the games graphical improvement is barely noticeable and somehow it can be improved beyond what it is simply by mods in the old verson.I just can't think of any reason you would spend your money on this. There is nothing here that is worth your money. At all.Oh but that is not even CLOSE to the worst of it! I will be running down that list.1 They had the dignity to hide the standard version from the steam store so you can't even find it without a search on google. It is like they are refusing to acknowlege its existence.2 Lack of any real changes to the game at all. I challenge you to find a significant one which effects it in a positive and noticeable light to the average player.3 Creation Club. What else is there to say? It is restrictive glorified anti consumer microtransactions in a 5 year old $40 single player rpg. Some of which can even be found already for free and one of which should be in the base game to begin with.In summary this is the worst "remaster" I have ever seen. Go buy the old version instead don't spend your money on this greedy valueless trash. And most of all we need to stop the creation club before it gets out of control. F*ck you Bethesda.Final rating 3/10Assuming CC is removed Rating 5/10

review: The Elder Scrolls Skyrim what a way to continue after the amazing predecessor TES Oblivion. Skyrim has been an absolutely amazing title since is release in 2011. Again this game wasn't &amp still isn't perfect (Obviously because its from Bethesda D). I have spent a decent 1100 hours in Skyrim across PC Xbox 360 PS3 &amp PS4. Lets just say I am kind of a fan ) This game offers an experience that barely any other games can compare to. The map is quite large containing many areas to explore with a vast number of unique experiences in each one. Yes after your 100th dungeon you may start to get a bit bored because of repetetiveness but thats nothing that mods cannot fix.Playing the game for its first time will be a bit slow due to the inventory system &amp questline sometimes being a pain in the backside. It doesn't really matter in the end you'll quickly fall in love with the game despite the not so rare crashes that will occur (Thanks Bethesda). The main story will keep you occupied for well over 15 hours on your first playthrough but thats not it! The amount of guilds (Mages Thieves &amp Dark Brotherhood) offer a highly diverse questline that you'll never forget.FAQ Q Is this game good?A Dumb question just buy it and enjoy it like so many have since 2011!Q What do I do once I complete the main story?A You play the DLC's (Which are great btw) and complete the guilds &amp faction quests. Q What do I do after completeing most quests &amp areas?A Either quit (Lose out on so much) or you can hop on over to the modding community. The modding site called the 'Nexus' &amp the integrated modding system from Bethesda will easily get you well over the 100 hours mark.Q Why would I mod is it hard to do so?A Modding can be very simple by using the In game one or slighly harder with the Nexus one (Tutorials on youtube around 5 minutes long). So the reason for modding is simply that it adds an infinite amount of content. There are some absolutely amazing content creators out there that have amazing DLC sized mods which are FREE! Want new enemies FREE! Want new lands to travel to FREE! Want to turn Skyrim into a tropical paradise FREE!Lets be honest here everyone has Skyrim or has at least heard of it. If you're still hesitating after all this time just grab it on one of the sales for so cheap. Remember there is a refund button which you won't use it anyway ) Hope on over into this amazing installment in The Elder Scrolls series and explore Skyrim!

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Got this game free because I already had Skyrim. Spent only a few minutes in this game comparing with the original. My personal verdict is that if you don't already own Skyrim there's no major reason to not get Special Edition instead of the original. But if you have the original you might as well stick to it with the official high def texture pack and a couple water mods maybe a saturation mod and a shadow banding fix mod if you want to go all out. Which chances are you already have installed.It doesn't look much different and what few differences exist I personally did not like or didn't think were worth dealing with the couple changes I didn't like.Also speaking of mods if you want to use mods on Special Edition it apparently disables achievements. You also apparently have to create a Bethesda account or somesuch in order to use mods. I didn't look too closely into it so maybe it's not a requirement if you work around it. But it's worth knowing.I copy pasted a save file from regular skyrim into special edition and took a couple comparison screen shots. Below I will link the original version screenshots in their descriptions they have links to the corresponding special edition screenshots.http //steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id 843562083http //steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id 843561842http //steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id 843561682http //steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id 843561511Something I noticed that I didn't see in other reviews not that I looked too closely at them was that in special edition the camera is weirdly "zoomed in" in first person mode. Like it's as if the camera is a foot and a half farther in front of your face in special edition than it was in the original. It's very disorienting I kept feeling like I was going to smack my face into something or Serana would pop up and be RIGHT IN MY FACE.It is of course up to you to decide which version you like better. I and a couple friends I showed these screenshots to preferred the original. But if you own the original and are wondering whether to bother installing the special edition.... Nah I wouldn't recommend it.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Warning! Evidently they removed the SteamWorkshop and Nexus Mod manager does NOT detect the exe file for this version so you can't install mods to it. Buyer Beware! If someone knows how to get around this please post here because I'm honestly pissied at not being able to install my mods into this!
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Before purchasing be aware that this game is capped at 60fps. There is a way to disable it HOWEVER doing so will break the game's physics and make it unplayable. Therefore this game must be played at 60fps. If you are used to high fps on high refresh monitors this game is not for you unless you can bear 60fps.

review: Product received for free. Ultrawide support?......It just works huh?Good thing I didn't pay for this quick buck.

review: Product received for free. I wish there was a neutral option for reviewing. I love Skyrim but this just doesn't warrant enough for a purchase and that's what my review is for. If you already own the game + DLCs then you have the game so no ned to worry. But when it comes to people who are looking to get into Skyrim for the first time I'd say wait a bit till the mods really start pourin in or for a sale.Right now the same bugs are still in the game so Bethesda still expects us to fix it. The textures are the same the only real difference is lighting effects some more flora and water textures. However the 64 bit boost is a huuuuge thing for mods but right now it doesn't mean anything since SKSE doesn't work yet.Anyway I'll change this when this game is actually worth its price. I recommend if you're a noob just get the original and soup it up with mods and you'll be fine.UPDATE Paid mods have come to skyrim and they hid the original. Get it off a key site or from herehttp //store.steampowered.com/app/72850/The_Elder_Scrolls_V_Skyrim/

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. It's Skyrim as we all know it. Now in 64 bit.The remaster or "special edition" really doesnt bring anything worth 40 to the table.If you had mods for the original Skyrim it probably looked better than this.During gameplay the only things I really noticed being different were the foilage and DoF effects.Bugs are untouched even worsened sometimes.Knowledge with console commands is almost a must as the game breaks itself constantly.Every exploit I knew from 2011 still works assuming it wasn't patched in the original already.Blackscreens and Crashes seem to be less frequent but are still present.Objectively the game runs worse than the original not by much though.This version was intended to bring 1080p and nice visuals to the newer consoles.But this is PC where we had 1080p and vis mods for almost 5 years now.If you got it for free there is no reason not to give it a shot but don't buy it.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: It's regular ol' skyrim just with more realisitc lighting. That's it. No new content no enhanced meshes or textures no fixes to cruddy npc AI or anything of the sort. If you already have vanilla skyrim there is NO reason to spend money on this. I already had the full set so I got it for free but I would never even consider "upgrading" otherwise. You can get a much better experience with regular skyrim just by adding a few choice mods. I really don't know why bethesda even made this a thing. They could've just made a lighting patch for the original. Seriously why does this exist?!

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Looks a miniscule amount better and performs noticeably worse. While the special edition does have some changes that will make a big difference under the hood like a 64 bit engine and no more blocky shadows there's almost nothing here on the surface. The audio quality is also much worse and if this is going to be your first time playing Skyrim I would recommend the original or waiting a few months to get this version when there are more ported mods available and some of the issues have been sorted out.Oh and alt+tab works now so that's a plus I guess.By the way I got it for free and I'm not complaining so stop saying that I am in the comments.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: This is the same amazing game as we know it but now even better. The Special Edition includes new features like remastered art and effects volumetric god rays dynamic depth of field screen space reflections reworked textures improved draw distance improved combat distance reworked colors and more. It's also on a 64bit engine now which is way more stable and especially if you like to improve it with mods.There's no point giving this game a negative review since it's the beautiful Skyrim as we know it but now with (slightly) improved graphics. If your modded original Skyrim was 'more beautiful' than this Remaster you can make this Remaster even MORE beautiful than your old save thanks to the better base game and it's 64 bit engine.Besides this was a free upgrade for those who already owned Skyrim + All DLC so I see no reason to complain. Skyrim is my favorite game of all time and now it's even better.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. Got it for free because I already own Skyrim with all DLC however It's still the same game as the original Skyrim. Nothing really has changed. If you have to pay money for it probably not worth it. Buy Oblivion instead if you've never played it.The graphics aren't that much better. The "graphical improvements" look like minimal texture upgrades a little added foliage and a few more shadows. If you have a working modded Skyrim already I wouldn't even waste time moving over to the special edition.Skyrim itself is a good game worth buying. If you don't have either version the special edition wouldn't be a bad place to start.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

I love skyrim but the magic of customization and updating through modding has simply been eliminated.This is the company that made fun of EA. Might as well join them they made mods microtransactions. This company is very hypocritical with their behavior.

review: Skyrim V has become my favorite single player game it literally gives me anything I want and satisfies most of my needs with mods. mods play a big part in this game I can't imagine how console players can even play this without mods. but for us this is a great advantage to use the full PC power to create something awesome. it's been more than 7 years since Skyrim V's launch in 2011 (Special edition only adds visual improvements but actual release date stays the same) and still many people play it because mods don't let it get boring and they keep coming.Skyrim V is not a single game like I don't need to play Overwatch because I got D.VA and Mercy characters and official outfits in Skyrim.I don't need to play Nier Automata because I got the outfits and characters already in Skyrim and I made my 2B look more beautiful than the original 2B.Hope to see Skyrim VI soon from Bethesda with Better mod compatibility and less complications.10/10

Boosting the fidelity of texures just makes the bad animations even more apparent.No other quality of life changes that were immediately apparent.Literally every other annoying thing about Skyrim is still here but shinier.In other words unless you played Skyrim with no interface/quality of life mods normally this is a downgraded experience. Don't bother.

review: Product received for free. PROs SkyrimCONS Achievements locked with modsWe've been playing Skyrim Special Edition for five years0/10They could've remastered Arena Daggerfall Morrowind Battlespire Redguard or Oblivion or even one of the Elder Scrolls Travels like Shadowkey Dawnstar or Stormhold but instead decided to remaster the most recent and best looking might I add entry in the series Skyrim. review: Writing a negative review for one simple reason. This game has been out for a very long time it has been patched and fixed for years AND it has been re released with so many different PAID versions that by now it should be fully functional.I however experience a nearly game breaking bug that no one including google searches were able to actually resolve. Conjuration spells completely stopped working for me.Every single attempt to fix including removing shrines buffs magic resist you name it failed to fix the problem. People reported that cast speed could break the game and in some cases your save file could become completely corrupted which would also break the game.However you want to spin it I'm not OK with a 100% vanilla zero mod play of this game being broken to the point that I cannot cast spells from an entire school of magic. Other spells (including self buffs) worked fine but Conjuration would not after about level 17.

review: Skyrim is as perfect as always. I love this game but ...When you don't already own this game and you are thinking about purchasing it I can't recommend special edition due to workshop. Imagine two exactly same games one of which has steam workshop enabled and second got obstacles for mods like registration on bethesda and downloading mods externaly. Where is comfort in that? I need the game to be costumer friendly and bend to my needs. This is the reason I chose to recommend the old legendary edition of skyrim over this special edition. This is only port there is nothing new in this version so play it if you've recieved it for free (like me) or play the old one don't be afraid you won't miss anything by that!

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. I've been playing SSE for about 15 hours now (offline don't have wifi) and have nothing but good things to say about it. Bethesda really delivered what they promised. The softer aesthetics and new lighting and effects are phenomenal along with updated textures makes the game unbelievably beautiful. The fact that it is true 64 bit makes the game run very smoothly and load times are extremely quick for me. I've also noticed plenty of new dialogue throughout multiple quest lines. It saddens me to see this revamped Skyrim get such a bad rap for all the wrong reasons and from people who don't pay attention to all the little beautiful details added to the game. I will be playing this version of Skyrim for quite sometime and hope new and old players aren't swayed from playing an even more exciting and optimized version of Skyrim!
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Skyrim is a massive open world action RPG with an open ended skill and progression system that adapts to and rewards your playstyle. Quests never feel like hum drum fetch quests and apart from the main questline even the sidequests themselves encapsulate stories within stories.SE also features 64 bit enhanced memory support and a plethora of visual upgrades that make the world sharper the shadows more shadowy and the sunrises well...more sunrisey.As a bonus it also fixes the game's previous alt tabbing problems.I've previously put hundreds of hours into the original console release before purchasing it on the PC as well.After purchasing it on PC I was pleasantly surprised when it was later announced that previous legendary edition owners would get SE for free as well...despite people claiming how greedy Bethesda is.Creation Club Bethesda recently announced (June 2017) that they would be releasing a curated content marketplace at E3. This caused an uproar on the Steam forums (for whatever that's worth) in large part due to the fiasco that was the previous workshop store on Steam which was widely panned.You can read about it here https //creationclub.bethesda.net/enThis led to many people mass downvoting the game and downvoting any positive reviews in protest as well as flamewars in the forums.Many of these negative claims are based on hyperbole and misinformation from people who haven't read the official FAQ and have made a lot of assumptions and rumors and then got outraged about the rumors that they made up. There has been some intelligent discussion on the subject in the Skyrim Steam forums but it was mostly drowned out.You can still purchase the original Skyrim on Steam.http //store.steampowered.com/app/72850/The_Elder_Scrolls_V_Skyrim/SE doesn't require you to use its built in mod manager nor does it force you to buy content from Bethesda only. NexusMods has over 6000 mods that support SE.If you read the Creation Club faq Bethesda also states they will continue to support the free and open modding community.Content creators will be screened by Bethesda and have to show examples of their work before being accepted to the program and all content will go through an approval process and development pipeline so the kid that tried to sell $99 horse genitals on the old workshop store isn't going to cut it here.If you were following this drama you should also know that the mudcrab armor for Skyrim and the horse armor for FO4 were inside jokes based on old memes. Apparently a lot of people didn't get them and took them 100% seriously.Bethesda has also stated that they will not be accepting pre existing mods for the creator program and they will be releasing new and original content.If you don't like content marketplaces that allow users to submit content and if approved get a share of the sales then you shouldn't support CSGO TF2 Dota 2 and many other games on Steam. This isn't the first single player game to sell content like skins either. In fact this also describes how the Steam store works too. Publishers and developers submit their content Steam sells it and takes a cut of all their sales.Now if you just don't like the idea then there's nothing wrong with that. But there are/were many users on the Steam forums shouting profanities slurs bigotry telling people to themselves talking about murdering the developers and claiming that anyone who doesn't agree with them is being paid by Bethesda. Don't be like those people.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Its a good game i have played it for a long time but like everybody else they need to get rid of the paid mods.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. TL DR longer review below. Don't bother modded Legendary Edition is just fine.Two hours is enough to remind me why I hated Vanilla Skyrim so much. The best game to play right now is the waiting game as we wait for the modders to port their mods over to this so called "Special Edition". If you played Skyrim on consoles or you don't care about mods at all then yes I recommend this game. It's not that Skyrim on release date was a terrible game. It deserved all the praise it received back in the day. But after several hundred hours of playing modded Skyrim the shocking reduction in quality playing Special Edition with no mods is jarring. Yes the graphics are better and because of this many HD mods become redundant which can help save hard drive space for those with only mid range PCs like myself. But how good are the remastered graphics? Sadly not very. Here's an excellent example at how lazy Bethesda is at remastering graphics. http //www.nexusmods.com/skyrimspecialedition/mods/659/? This mod shows in detail how low res the textures and meshes are even in this Special Edition. Now I know what you are saying "Well of course mods are going to be better than vanilla that's the point of modding." I hear what you are saying but consider the following. Bethesda is a huge developer/publisher with millions of dollars hundreds of staff and had months to work on this remastered project. This author worked alone and released the original version for vanilla Skyrim exactly three months after its release date. All the author needed to do was port over all the assets he already had for vanilla Skyrim and Bob's your uncle. Why didn't Bethesda take the time to give this Special Edition the love and care it deserves? Answer because they don't give a they just want your money so they take the game make it 64 bit slap some god rays on it and call it a new game. Also the lack of improvement was that the game could still run on consoles. When are companies going to stop treating PC players like second class citizens when they have far more money than console players on average? My PC was relatively cheap at about $1300 CDN. A PS4 can be purchased for $450 CDN brand new. A $1300 PC and a $450 console are never going to be equal. PC is always going to be the most powerful gaming platform. Deal with it stop pretending and stopping screwing over the customer base with the most amount of money. Even someone working a minimum wage job full time can save up to buy a console in as little as couple of weeks depending on how badly they want it. Don't fall for their nonsense. I got this game for free from owning Legendary Edition and I still don't recommend it. If you've never owned Skyrim before buy the original Legendary Edition and just add mods. The modding community has not abandoned vanilla Skyrim and is unlikely to for a very long time if ever considering that mods for Oblivion and Fallout 3 are still being released.To sum up as a remastered edition I am not impressed. Vanilla Skyrim was an awesome game modded Skyrim is even more so. This version? Just no don't bother. Don't reward greed and laziness by paying money for this game and if you got it for free don't rush to download it as the best mods on Nexus are going to be weeks and months away from Special Edition compatibility. Let's face it nobody buys Bethesda games for their vanilla content they buy it so they can mod the hell out of it and make a better game. Hell the whole point of this release on console was to add mod support. Even Bethesda knows modders make a better product than they do. Again do not reward this behaviour by spending money on this product or they will keep doing the same ad nauseum.

review: Product received for free. Well first of all I can't seem to ALT TAB which means that since the game doesn't have built in volume controls (lol?) I can't actually lower the ear deafening sounds that this game is producing. But that is really the last of the problems I currently have.For whatever reason I have no mouse input. I'm not even kidding. I can't navigate menus with my mouse and in game I can't move my character. I don't have a controller plugged in but if I remember from Skyrim you had to actually "activate" using a controller from the options. And that would be pretty easy to fix... Or it would be if the game actually gave me an "Options" menu from the start menu which for whatever reason it decided not to do.I tried pressing escape to bring up the options in game but since I can't use my keyboard the menu isn't actually popping up. I can't even comment on how the game runs because I honestly have no ing clue about how well it works. But from the single screen I've been able to see it looks pretty much the same as before.Great job Bethesda I thought Fallout 4 was your lowest quality game to date but you somehow beat my expectations once again.EDIT Tried changing the options from the INI file but it didn't fix the mouse problem. I'm out of ideas.

review: Product received for free. The Elders Scrolls V Skyrim Special EditionOk my third review for the special edition because I wasn't really happy and was able to play more. And sorry for my bad english I use my expandable english and google translate DI received this edition for free because I already have the normal version with all the DLC's and I loved the game and spent many hours in Skyrim. Therefore I recommend the regular version definitely but is it the same with the special edition? I would say maybe. NEW Short charging times due to the 64 bit Engine The new lighting effects look very good no stuttering when changing the current Cell Everything is generally more colorful and mostly realistic illuminated Dynamic FocusThe rest hasn't changed too hard. The quests are the same the faces are still emotionless ( D ) bugs were take... All in all it is ok but not awesome. If you played the normal version with mods that isn't a big upgrade for you...But it is still Skyrim in my view the best game of all time therefore I recommend it logically.The feeling is still awesome! Best regards EL inus
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Don't buy this if you own the original. Absolutely do not.This game is literally the same as the original release the only differences are the upgrade to 64 bit for extra RAM allocation and the removal of the Steam Workshop and replacing it with the Bethesda version which doesn't allow you to get achievements if you have any mods enabled in comparison to the original allowing you to get them with mods running.The audio is more compressed and sounds slightly worse on headphones and the textures were upscaled for some reason even though they look exactly the same. The only thing the graphics in this have going over the original is the better Antialiasing Depth of Field and the light diffusion that occurs with the god rays.Oh and there's more rocks on roads and a couple extra bushes. Yay.

review: The original skyrim (which is hidden from searching it up and can be found on trending with friends sometimes) was a great rpg and good game which most everyone liked. It wasn't my cup of tea but I like the engine and idea of it. The graphics were okay and somewhat hold up if you have a very low end pc. Then bethesda announces their biggest project to date SKYRIM SPECIAL EDITION the thing they have been spending all your time and money on. But what innovations does this game have? the water is 4k and it gives you all the dlc. That would be fine and dandy if not for it being unable to share the originals skyrims mods which was the main reason people even liked the original skyrim because it had so many issues. This was a big rant but buy the original if you actually want the game even if it costs more. I for one do not support this game even though i unfortunately had the displeasure of buying it on sale.Overall not worth it. The best thing going for it was mods which have not been transfered to its seperate nexus page and you do not want to use the bethesda given mods which encourage buying creation club mods Reading this is 500 creation club credits or $5.00 USD thanks for sitting through my ebic review bb.

It hardly reinvents the game but gives it a nice new level of polish to give an excuse for a revisit.However a review is aimed at those looking to buy the game. As of review the price is set at 30 which is an excessive price tag for a five year old game. The original is currently listed for 10.So the simple question is do I feel like I would have paid 20 for this upgrade? Nah absolutely not.Grab the original get some mods that update the visuals and you're set. Stick this on your wishlist for now the price will tumble eventually.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. As fun as it is to play though the game again the only thing Special about this Edition is how lazy Bethesda is. I'm going to assume that most of the graphical upgrades were due to Fallout 4's development since they are the same engine. The same bugs exist once they stopped patching Skyrim but what's funny is the audio is worse quality than the original's. And there is nothing new nothing that really makes this edition special other than its 64 bit.A lot of the best mods need Skyrim Script Extender which from what I understand has to be completely rewritten for this version of the game. It's also not done for Fallout 4 and who knows when it will be released for this edition. At least we don't have to pay for mods like they wanted although if they had hired some of the modders to fix some of the issues this would of been worthy of "special edition."Morrowind's and Oblivion's main stories felt finished. Here in Skyrim you can defeat the dragons but what of the Civil War? You pick your side and the cities change factions Jarls change. That's about it. What about the Thalmor? It just abruptly stops there no moot to declare who is High King of Skyrim. What about you as Dragonborn? Could you follow the path of Talos and become Emperor or at the very least High King of Skyrim to unite the land against the Dominion? Guess we won't know until Elder Scrolls VI and what they decide is canon.I'm still also probably going to put a hundred+ hours into this lol. TL DR They put a fresh coat of paint on a game that modders will scrape off and paint better.

review: Product received for free. What did I like? That that it was free. What I don't like? As I've seen several others say I also agree that Bethesda wasted a lot of time and money working on this when they should have been working on more deserving games and I DON'T just mean ES VI I mean either Morrowind or especially Oblivion(which DID just turn 10 this year!)! All the other developers have been releasing anniversary editions for their 10 year old games so why didn't Oblivion get its anniversary edition?!Don't get me wrong yes it does look prettier but only by a VERY SLIGHT improvement over all the environmental mods I had in my Legendary Edition of the game. Is it worth paying full price for the Special Edition? ABSOLUTELY NOT! As several others have also noticed VERY FEW bugs were fixed. Also the other thing I've seen quite a few others complaining about is that using mods in the SE DOES DISABLE Steam achievements and console Trophies/Acheivements so if you care about that go pick up the older version for dirt cheap as using mods in THAT version unlocks them just fine.Btw why is it asking me to check a box if I received it free? Does that mean you readers are automatically supposed to discount my review just because I didn't pay for it? It was nice for Bethesda to do that for Steam users but it's extremely unfair to charge FULL PRICE for console users for a 5 year old game when I've seen the Legendary Edition going for $20 new!

review: Product received for free. Not recommended because again Bethesda relies on other people to fix another one of their top products. I can manage with small bugs annoyances etc. but 1. Not being able to walk through open doors essentially preventing me from finishing quests without the use of the console or mods. Collisions are broken all around.2. Barnabas is EVEN MORE annoying which is almost impossible or so i thought.3. Random objects NPCs and animals can often be found floating in the air.4. Essenntially all of the original vanilla Skyrim bugs are transferred along with introducing new ones.(5. No achievements with or without mods or addons. EDIT I have not touched the game for a few days and suddently the achievements magically appeared go figure.)I'm sick of spending time fixing games instead of playing them. Considering that Fallout 4 is essentially Skyrim with guns and both games were released prior to Skyrim SE I thik Bethesda should do a better job working on a product rather than marketing it. After Thief 2014 i stopped bying Square Enix titles where you spend more time watching opening and closing windows rather than playing. Looks like my blacklist will be expading soon unless there are major improvemets in this product (Skyrim SE). Until then this review will stay negative.

review: Product received for free. + its free (My thanks is tempered by knowing that Bethesda knows there is nothing worth charging for here so they gave it away in the hopes to entice modders and users to port over to Bethesda.net and integrate with their console modding master plan)+ it does run quite fine on my aging HD7770 2GB (medium settings)+ does have prettier plants and better lighting/environment as advertised sometimes has the stutter/jerkiness that FO4 occasionaly exhibited for me..(not sure whats driving this..) it has hung up twice on exit almost forcing me to reboot my PC until it magically self resolved and returned control to me (worse behavior that my legendary edition and same kind of behavior I saw in FO4) All SKSE/FNIS based mods are toast for now RE this version doubt a lot of them will be ported because a lot of modders are moved on (real life or diff games) so thats a deal breaker. Legendary Edition + a few mods nets the equivalent or better look/feel as SSE After booting into SSE I remembered why I modded it (ugly faces and horrible console based UI) ugly face textures No SkyUI / iHUD no new content no fixes from unofficial patchTLDR * Negative review because they only released this to further Bethesda.net and entice mod makers to port to it. * Owners of Legendary edition can install 5 mods and get better performance and visuals (or close enough).* I have 4k hours in Skyrim and I LOVE the ES series but Bethesda is way in the weeds here. Come back guys...you done f'd it up.Edit Spelling/grammar

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. A welcome improvement but still room for improvement.I feel like graphically Skyrim SE is what 2011 Skyrim should have been a built in ENB (or very nearly so) better lighting high res textures depth of field (maybe even a little parallax?). The character models are oh kay good enough to play but still lacking the polish of say Mass Effect. The draw distance is still less than great and the water looks like flowing gel but as shipped it's 85% of the way there.The game also has considerable under the hood improvement. It opens in a near instant. Not a single crash thus far. Alt+tab works! (TOOK LONG ENOUGH.) Whiterun loaded in 2.5 *seconds*. I've never seen the framerate so consistently high or loading screens so consistently short. Took 10 years since 64 bit was common but it's here at last. Bravo.Gameplay wise Skyrim SE is still 2011 Skyrim through and through. It was actually shocking to remember what that was like as I'm coming from my heavily modded Frostfall+Requiem+EGO+Warzones hardcore gameplay installation of the original. I just beat Helgen on my first try not my 30th. Everything thus far has been a cake walk. Which reminds me of this article ( http //www.escapistmagazine.com/articles/view/video games/columns/firstperson/9265 Skyrim is Soulless ) and underscores sadly that original Skyrim as shipped is a sort of Potempkin village lots of pretty things to look at but it's all only skin deep. No real challenge no real choices or consequences. This new Skyrim SE *needs* to be modded if for no other reason than to compensate for the critical gameplay elements that are still lacking.Which finally brings me to the missed opportunities. Though some bugs (crashing) appear to have been alleviated there is a huge and unforgivable missed opportunity. The unofficial patches at a minimum should have been included essential as they are and given that Bethesda has known about these bugs for years. It also would have been nice to have seen the original cut content (e.g. Pit Fighters Cutting Room Floor Civil War Overhaul Touring Carriages) restored the argument that they ran out of time doesn't cut it 5 years later. Other obvious deficiencies (slow horses no body in first person no multiple followers no open cities no built in SkyUI) still remain unaddressed as well. Perhaps the biggest missed opportunity is that at the dawn of the VR age there is no built in VR support. VR enthusiasts will rue this day for years.Should you get Skyrim SE? Of course. Skyrim (modded) is a great game. I just wish that after 5 years Skryim were finally shipping as it should have shipped 5 years ago.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

Only this time you can enjoy it with prettier lights and some flowers. If you can get it to launch that it is. I swear I've never seen a game crash so many times just trying to get to the main screen. My original copy with mods looks and runs better than this. So glad I got it for free because this is a huge let down. Maybe after some patches (if there are any) this will get better. Still LOVE the game just with the company being greedy like everyone else. Why are you all turning into EA? At this point a modded out orginal/legendary copy is better than this if you are looking to buy. Will update if things improve.

NOTHING improved or fixed about quests AI meshes/texture bugs engine bugs (which can't be fixed modding the game even through Unofficial patches). title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. When Skyrim first came out I had been so eager to play it. First owned it on the Xbox 360 for which it was a mind blowing experience instantly fell in love with the game. I moved to pc shortly after which only improved the game vastly. It was a medium level laptop I ran it on but the game still felt fresh.Coming back to it five years later there honestly isn't much that stands out. Obviously it's the same game plot and structure but nothing about the new and improved graphics and atmosphere feels well....new. The special edition has had a five year gap and between the two games many modders have managed to achieve even more than some of the new features...they simply don't reflect on what should have been. Sun shafts some slightly improved fire physics and redone textures are about as noticable as it gets (even though the hd textures were already available years prior). Other than that there doesn't appear to be anything visually striking. Even the poor NPC's still have those lifeless eyes...I mean if interection with them is such a big part of the game could they not have made them nicer to look at? This is a strictly Ultra settings opinion...as for the console users I have no doubt that things look nicer. The new edition for PCs however if you aren't recieving it for FREE is not in my opinion worth it. Mods within the Steam community are far more effective and will make you awe at the little details whereas the new edition will make you question the hype you spilled waiting for it to happen. It is a shame that such a title as Skyrim suffered of recent and I cannot honestly see myself delving into another 800 hours of gameplay.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. I'll never understand the adoration for this game.By no means is Skyrim bad. It's pretty good but it's no where near as amazing as so many built it up to be. It's a shallow RPG with a good lore that is squandered.It isn't Fallout 4 but goddamn a little effort would be nice.As for the Special Edition it's Skyrim. What do you expect? Unless you're a spaz that installs loads of mods this is superior to the regular version.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: Product received for free. One note I dont think anyone noticed yet character managment on PC.. finally I dont need to scroll thru 900+ saves to find a diff character...Honestly the loading is fast barely any fps drops/lag on ultra (Nivdia730M) the engine can handle so much more now since moving to 64bit and I'm excited to see if it can handle my 200+ mods like I had on the original (that crashed frequently even w/ patches/loot/merged patches/other optimization on medium quality)Stability is the name of the game now tbh you still have the classic beth bugs and glitches but the whole game is much more stable and able to handle large mob spawns.Is it worth 40? yeah esp if you havent played in a while to me tho I would wait for a sale if you missed the free distrib. cuz you didnt have all the DLC.The modding community has come back w/ force and fantastic mods have been ported already!

review: So far so good. I'm not sure why people are complaining about bad optimization... I'm running this on a 5 year old ROG laptop with a Nvidia 560M card... and it's running flawlessly (albeit on low settings.) The biggest difference is the load times. HOLY MOTHER OF CTHULHU the game loads like 10 times faster... I haven't encountered any bugs. The graphical updates do look good even on low detail. Mods are being ported over to Special Edition... It was free... It's literally just Skyrim with a few updates. And that's fine. All these people who don't recommend a free update to a game that's just an all time high for whining.

DONT BUY ANYTHING FROM CREATION CLUB USE YOUR BRAIN.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: We only got it free since its PC that makes the mods. I bet they only did this to bring mods to console so that they can later bring back paid mods like they said they would. Most people look at it like "oh free candy" but nothing is truly free... This game just split the modding community and who knows what the big mods like skywind and skyblivion will do at this point.Old mods will be ported but not all. Problem is that we now have a split community with the more important mod projects lost in the middle. I cant say im happy with this the remastered looks worse then my old modded one and now im stuck wondering the fate of the major mod projects that would be remaking older TES games that actually NEED to be updated. Leave it to Bethesda to tear the community apart by trying to cash in on their modders. If you dont see whats going on.. open your eyes.
title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim Special Edition

review: It's Skyrim what to say? In short Great exploration insane ammount of quests killing people with swords axes maces magic 'n stuff overall a sh*t ton of stuff to do. Now about the Special Edition First of all it's either better or just as good as the Legendary Edition in every way.The graphics are overall nicer with new Godrays depth of field and much better shadows.Things like bugs and UI (excecpt the new "Mods" category in the main menu) were literally untouched (so no bug fixes gotta admit I'm disappointed).But the biggest change is the ditching of x32 and upgrade to x64 of the engine meaning it performs better than original Skyrim expecially in crowded areas even though the graphics are better aswell not to forget that this opens up a whole new level of high demanding mods to be created from a modding community still working after 5 years sicne the original Skyrim came out.But as conclusion I have to say I wouldn't buy it for 40 (got it for free like many others for having the normal game with all DLC) but if you get this as game key or on a sale for 30 or less I can highly recommend it (oh and if you don't own Skyrim at all it's worth the full price IMO).
